mn140:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā magadhesu cārikaṃ caramāno yena rājagahaṃ tadavasari;
mn140:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the Magadhan lands when he arrived at Rājagaha.

mn140:1.3.pli: yena bhaggavo kumbhakāro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhaggavaṃ kumbhakāraṃ etadavoca:
mn140:1.3.eng: He went to see Bhaggava the potter, and said,
mn140:1.3.comm: The Bhaggava clan was descended from the ancient sage Bhagu (Sanskrit Bhṛgu). They received the gift of fire conveyed by Mātariśvan the wind from the god Agni (eg. Rig Veda 1.60.1). In Pali they appear as potters (MN 81:19.3, SN 1.50:11.2, SN 2.24:12.2), unless they have gone forth (DN 24:1.1.6). Archaeologists refer to the strata around the Buddha’s time as the Northern Black Polished Ware culture on account of the distinctive highly glazed polish that was achieved on the pottery of the time. This, together with the production of iron, marked a significant advance in the mastery of fire. Thus potters were no mere humble craftsmen, but leading technological innovators.

mn140:2.1.pli: “sace te, bhaggava, agaru viharemu āvesane ekarattan”ti.
mn140:2.1.eng: “Bhaggava, if it is no trouble, I’d like to spend a single night in your workshop.”

mn140:2.3.eng: But there’s a renunciate already staying there.

mn140:2.4.pli: Sace so anujānāti, viharatha, bhante, yathāsukhan”ti.
mn140:2.4.eng: If he allows it, sir, you may stay as long as you please.”

mn140:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pukkusāti nāma kulaputto bhagavantaṃ uddissa saddhāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
mn140:3.1.eng: Now at that time a gentleman named Pukkusāti had gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness in the Buddha’s name.
mn140:3.1.comm: Buddhist texts of the middle period—starting a few centuries after the Buddha—share the story that Pukkusāti had been the king of Taxila in Gandhāra, who went forth out of faith upon reading texts of the Dhamma sent by his friend and ally, Bimbisāra. This story is found in detail in the Pali commentary to this sutta, and more briefly in several canonical texts of the northern traditions (T 211 at T iv 580c19; T 511 at T xiv 779a; Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya 3.2.26, which spells his name puṣkarasāri, the same name as the brahmin known in Pali as Pokkharasāti). Texts of this period also know of a script called puṣkarasāri (Lalitavistara 10, Vaidya 87; Mahāvastu 14, Senart 1.135). This would presumably have been the writing system in the city of Puṣkarāvati, another city in Gandhāra, the region where the oldest surviving Buddhist manuscripts have been found. The details of the Pukkusāti legend are improbable and it is mostly likely an origin myth suggested by the similarity of his name with Puṣkarāvati, authorizing the establishment of the Dhamma in Gandhāra in the post-Ashokan period, as well as offering a precedent for the writing down of the Dhamma.

mn140:3.2.pli: So tasmiṃ kumbhakārāvesane paṭhamaṃ vāsūpagato hoti.
mn140:3.2.eng: And it was he who had first taken up residence in the workshop.

mn140:3.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yenāyasmā pukkusāti tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ pukkusātiṃ etadavoca:
mn140:3.3.eng: Then the Buddha approached Venerable Pukkusāti and said,

mn140:3.4.pli: “sace te, bhikkhu, agaru viharemu āvesane ekarattan”ti.
mn140:3.4.eng: “Mendicant, if it is no trouble, I’d like to spend a single night in the workshop.”
mn140:3.4.comm: The Buddha addresses Pukkusāti as “mendicant” (bhikkhu), implicitly recognizing him as a Buddhist monk (compare MN 26:24.5 = MN 85:48.5), while Pukkusāti uses the respectful familiar form “reverend” (āvuso).

mn140:3.6.eng: Stay as long as you please.”

mn140:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā kumbhakārāvesanaṃ pavisitvā ekamantaṃ tiṇasanthārakaṃ paññāpetvā nisīdi pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
mn140:4.1.eng: Then the Buddha entered the workshop and spread out a grass mat to one side. He sat down cross-legged, set his body straight, and established mindfulness in his presence.

mn140:4.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā bahudeva rattiṃ nisajjāya vītināmesi.
mn140:4.2.eng: He spent much of the night sitting in meditation,

mn140:4.3.pli: Āyasmāpi kho pukkusāti bahudeva rattiṃ nisajjāya vītināmesi.

mn140:4.4.eng: Then it occurred to the Buddha,

mn140:4.5.comm: He had been sitting most of the night in meditation, indicating that he had already mastered immersion to a substantial degree. The commentary says that he had in fact attained the fourth absorption based on mindfulness of breathing.

mn140:4.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ pukkusātiṃ etadavoca:
mn140:4.7.eng: So the Buddha said to Pukkusāti,

mn140:5.1.pli: “kaṃsi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, uddissa pabbajito? Ko vā te satthā? Kassa vā tvaṃ dhammaṃ rocesī”ti?
mn140:5.1.eng: “In whose name have you gone forth, mendicant? Who is your Teacher? Whose teaching do you believe in?”

mn140:5.2.eng: “Reverend, there is the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family.

mn140:5.3.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhagavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

mn140:5.4.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
mn140:5.4.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

mn140:5.5.eng: I’ve gone forth in his name.

mn140:5.6.eng: That Blessed One is my Teacher,

mn140:5.7.eng: and I believe in his teaching.”

mn140:5.8.pli: “Kahaṃ pana, bhikkhu, etarahi so bhagavā viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho”ti.
mn140:5.8.eng: “But mendicant, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”

mn140:5.9.eng: “In the northern lands there is a city named Sāvatthī.
mn140:5.9.comm: Compare AN 2.37:4.2, where Sāvatthī is said to be in the east (probably from Madhurā).

mn140:5.10.pli: Tattha so bhagavā etarahi viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho”ti.
mn140:5.10.eng: There the Blessed One is now staying, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.”

mn140:5.11.eng: “But have you ever seen that Buddha?

mn140:5.12.eng: Would you recognize him if you saw him?”

mn140:5.13.pli: “Na kho me, āvuso, diṭṭhapubbo so bhagavā;

mn140:5.14.eng: and I wouldn’t recognize him if I did.”
mn140:5.14.comm: Despite his wisdom, Pukkusāti fails to recognize the Buddha. In other cases such failure is a narrative indication of spiritual blindness (Ajātasattu at DN 2:11.2 and the park keeper at MN 31:3.4 = MN 128:0.2 = Kd 10:4.2.3).

mn140:6.1.eng: Then it occurred to the Buddha,

mn140:6.2.eng: “This gentleman has gone forth in my name.

mn140:6.3.eng: Why don’t I teach him the Dhamma?”
mn140:6.3.comm: The Buddha leads by persuading with the Dhamma, rather than by revealing his identity.

mn140:6.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ pukkusātiṃ āmantesi:
mn140:6.4.eng: So the Buddha said to Pukkusāti,

mn140:6.5.eng: “Mendicant, I shall teach you the Dhamma.

mn140:6.6.pli: Taṃ suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn140:6.6.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn140:7.1.pli: “‘Cha dhāturo ayaṃ, bhikkhu, puriso cha phassāyatano aṭṭhārasa manopavicāro caturādhiṭṭhāno;
mn140:7.1.eng: “‘This person has six elements, six fields of contact, eighteen mental preoccupations, and four foundations.
mn140:7.1.comm: The six elements, six fields of contact, eighteen mental preoccupations are taught at AN 3.61:9.3ff., where they are followed by the four noble truths.

mn140:7.2.pli: yattha ṭhitaṃ maññassavā nappavattanti, maññassave kho pana nappavattamāne muni santoti vuccati.
mn140:7.2.eng: Where they stand, the streams of conceiving do not flow. And where the streams of conceiving do not flow, they are called a sage at peace.

mn140:7.3.pli: Paññaṃ nappamajjeyya, saccamanurakkheyya, cāgamanubrūheyya, santimeva so sikkheyyā’ti—
mn140:7.3.eng: Do not neglect wisdom; preserve truth; foster generosity; and train only for peace.’

mn140:7.4.eng: This is the summary recital for the analysis of the elements.

mn140:8.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn140:8.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn140:8.4.pli: pathavīdhātu, āpodhātu, tejodhātu, vāyodhātu, ākāsadhātu, viññāṇadhātu.
mn140:8.4.eng: the elements of earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.
mn140:8.4.comm: First the Buddha establishes the fundamental scope of his teaching. The elements describe the world as it is, and on them the course of meditation is based. The extension of the four elements to six hints at the practice of formless attainments.

mn140:8.6.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn140:8.6.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn140:9.1.eng: ‘This person has six fields of contact.’

mn140:9.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn140:9.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn140:9.3.pli: Cakkhusamphassāyatanaṃ, sotasamphassāyatanaṃ, ghānasamphassāyatanaṃ, jivhāsamphassāyatanaṃ, kāyasamphassāyatanaṃ, manosamphassāyatanaṃ.
mn140:9.3.eng: The fields of contact of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

mn140:9.4.eng: ‘This person has six fields of contact.’

mn140:9.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn140:9.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn140:10.1.comm: The “fields of contact” are the scope within which experience occurs, in response to which one becomes “preoccupied” due to the power of feeling. See note on MN 137:8.1.

mn140:10.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn140:10.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn140:10.3.pli: Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā somanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicarati, domanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicarati, upekkhāṭṭhāniyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicarati;
mn140:10.3.eng: Seeing a sight with the eye, one is preoccupied with a sight that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity.

mn140:10.4.eng: Hearing a sound with the ear …

mn140:10.5.eng: Smelling an odor with the nose …

mn140:10.6.eng: Tasting a flavor with the tongue …

mn140:10.7.eng: Feeling a touch with the body …

mn140:10.8.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya somanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ dhammaṃ upavicarati, domanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ dhammaṃ upavicarati, upekkhāṭṭhāniyaṃ dhammaṃ upavicarati—
mn140:10.8.eng: Becoming conscious of an idea with the mind, one is preoccupied with an idea that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity.

mn140:10.9.pli: iti cha somanassupavicārā, cha domanassupavicārā, cha upekkhupavicārā.
mn140:10.9.eng: So there are six preoccupations with happiness, six preoccupations with sadness, and six preoccupations with equanimity.

mn140:10.11.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn140:10.11.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn140:11.1.comm: Thus far we have dealt with what is in the world (the elements), how we experience the world (contact), and how we react to that experience (preoccupation with feeling). Now the Buddha turns to the path; instead of uncritical reaction to feeling, we develop a reflective response.

mn140:11.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn140:11.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn140:11.3.eng: The foundations of wisdom, truth, generosity, and peace.
mn140:11.3.comm: “Foundation” is adhiṭṭhāna, one meaning of which is the “plinth” or “base” on which a building rests; the commentary glosses with patiṭṭhā. Also at DN 33:1.11.150.

mn140:11.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn140:11.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn140:12.1.pli: ‘Paññaṃ nappamajjeyya, saccamanurakkheyya, cāgamanubrūheyya, santimeva so sikkheyyā’ti—
mn140:12.1.eng: ‘Do not neglect wisdom; preserve truth; foster generosity; and train only for peace.’
mn140:12.1.comm: Here the Buddha echoes the pattern of his first discourse, where he first identified what the four noble truths are, then identified the duty or task to be undertaken in relation to each of them (SN 56.11; see also SN 56.12, SN 56.29).

mn140:12.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn140:12.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn140:13.1.eng: And how does one not neglect wisdom?
mn140:13.1.comm: Thus begins the longest section of the discourse, continuing up to MN 140:25.3.

mn140:13.2.comm: The Buddha returns to the six elements, for which we have already been prepared in brief. The discussion of the “elements” (dhātu) now continues in similar fashion to the five elements at MN 62:8.1. MN 28:5.1 teaches the four “principal states” (mahābhūta) in even more detail.

mn140:13.3.pli: pathavīdhātu, āpodhātu, tejodhātu, vāyodhātu, ākāsadhātu, viññāṇadhātu.
mn140:13.3.eng: the elements of earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.

mn140:14.1.eng: And what is the earth element?

mn140:14.2.eng: The earth element may be interior or exterior.

mn140:14.3.eng: And what is the interior earth element?

mn140:14.4.pli: Yaṃ ajjhattaṃ paccattaṃ kakkhaḷaṃ kharigataṃ upādinnaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
mn140:14.4.eng: Anything internal, personal, that’s hard, solid, and appropriated. This includes:

mn140:14.5.pli: kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco maṃsaṃ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṃ vakkaṃ hadayaṃ yakanaṃ kilomakaṃ pihakaṃ papphāsaṃ antaṃ antaguṇaṃ udariyaṃ karīsaṃ, yaṃ vā panaññampi kiñci ajjhattaṃ paccattaṃ kakkhaḷaṃ kharigataṃ upādinnaṃ—
mn140:14.5.eng: head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, or anything else internal, personal, that’s hard, solid, and appropriated.

mn140:14.6.eng: This is called the interior earth element.

mn140:14.7.pli: Yā ceva kho pana ajjhattikā pathavīdhātu yā ca bāhirā pathavīdhātu pathavīdhāturevesā.
mn140:14.7.eng: The interior earth element and the exterior earth element are just the earth element.

mn140:14.8.pli: ‘Taṃ netaṃ mama nesohamasmi na meso attā’ti—evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
mn140:14.8.eng: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn140:14.9.pli: Evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā pathavīdhātuyā nibbindati, pathavīdhātuyā cittaṃ virājeti.
mn140:14.9.eng: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the earth element, detaching the mind from the earth element.

mn140:15.1.eng: And what is the water element?

mn140:15.2.eng: The water element may be interior or exterior.

mn140:15.3.eng: And what is the interior water element?

mn140:15.4.pli: Yaṃ ajjhattaṃ paccattaṃ āpo āpogataṃ upādinnaṃ seyyathidaṃ—
mn140:15.4.eng: Anything internal, personal, that’s water, watery, and appropriated. This includes:

mn140:15.5.pli: pittaṃ semhaṃ pubbo lohitaṃ sedo medo assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttaṃ, yaṃ vā panaññampi kiñci ajjhattaṃ paccattaṃ āpo āpogataṃ upādinnaṃ—
mn140:15.5.eng: bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine, or anything else internal, personal, that’s water, watery, and appropriated.

mn140:15.6.eng: This is called the interior water element.

mn140:15.7.pli: Yā ceva kho pana ajjhattikā āpodhātu yā ca bāhirā āpodhātu āpodhāturevesā.
mn140:15.7.eng: The interior water element and the exterior water element are just the water element.

mn140:15.8.pli: ‘Taṃ netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
mn140:15.8.eng: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn140:15.9.pli: Evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā āpodhātuyā nibbindati, āpodhātuyā cittaṃ virājeti.
mn140:15.9.eng: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the water element, detaching the mind from the water element.

mn140:16.1.eng: And what is the fire element?

mn140:16.2.eng: The fire element may be interior or exterior.

mn140:16.3.eng: And what is the interior fire element?

mn140:16.4.pli: Yaṃ ajjhattaṃ paccattaṃ tejo tejogataṃ upādinnaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
mn140:16.4.eng: Anything internal, personal, that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated. This includes:

mn140:16.5.pli: yena ca santappati, yena ca jīrīyati, yena ca pariḍayhati, yena ca asitapītakhāyitasāyitaṃ sammā pariṇāmaṃ gacchati, yaṃ vā panaññampi kiñci ajjhattaṃ paccattaṃ tejo tejogataṃ upādinnaṃ—
mn140:16.5.eng: that which warms, that which ages, that which heats you up when feverish, that which properly digests food and drink; or anything else internal, personal, that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated.

mn140:16.6.eng: This is called the interior fire element.

mn140:16.7.pli: Yā ceva kho pana ajjhattikā tejodhātu yā ca bāhirā tejodhātu tejodhāturevesā.
mn140:16.7.eng: The interior fire element and the exterior fire element are just the fire element.

mn140:16.8.pli: ‘Taṃ netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
mn140:16.8.eng: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn140:16.9.pli: Evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā tejodhātuyā nibbindati, tejodhātuyā cittaṃ virājeti.
mn140:16.9.eng: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the fire element, detaching the mind from the fire element.

mn140:17.1.eng: And what is the air element?

mn140:17.2.eng: The air element may be interior or exterior.

mn140:17.3.eng: And what is the interior air element?

mn140:17.4.pli: Yaṃ ajjhattaṃ paccattaṃ vāyo vāyogataṃ upādinnaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
mn140:17.4.eng: Anything internal, personal, that’s air, airy, and appropriated. This includes:

mn140:17.5.pli: uddhaṅgamā vātā adhogamā vātā kucchisayā vātā koṭṭhāsayā vātā aṅgamaṅgānusārino vātā assāso passāso iti, yaṃ vā panaññampi kiñci ajjhattaṃ paccattaṃ vāyo vāyogataṃ upādinnaṃ—
mn140:17.5.eng: winds that go up or down, winds in the belly or the bowels, winds that flow through the limbs, in-breaths and out-breaths; or anything else internal, personal, that’s air, airy, and appropriated.

mn140:17.6.eng: This is called the interior air element.

mn140:17.7.pli: Yā ceva kho pana ajjhattikā vāyodhātu yā ca bāhirā vāyodhātu vāyodhāturevesā.
mn140:17.7.eng: The interior air element and the exterior air element are just the air element.

mn140:17.8.pli: ‘Taṃ netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
mn140:17.8.eng: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn140:17.9.pli: Evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā vāyodhātuyā nibbindati, vāyodhātuyā cittaṃ virājeti.
mn140:17.9.eng: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the air element, detaching the mind from the air element.

mn140:18.1.eng: And what is the space element?

mn140:18.2.eng: The space element may be interior or exterior.

mn140:18.3.eng: And what is the interior space element?

mn140:18.4.pli: Yaṃ ajjhattaṃ paccattaṃ ākāsaṃ ākāsagataṃ upādinnaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
mn140:18.4.eng: Anything internal, personal, that’s space, spacious, and appropriated. This includes:

mn140:18.5.pli: kaṇṇacchiddaṃ nāsacchiddaṃ mukhadvāraṃ yena ca asitapītakhāyitasāyitaṃ ajjhoharati, yattha ca asitapītakhāyitasāyitaṃ santiṭṭhati, yena ca asitapītakhāyitasāyitaṃ adhobhāgaṃ nikkhamati, yaṃ vā panaññampi kiñci ajjhattaṃ paccattaṃ ākāsaṃ ākāsagataṃ aghaṃ aghagataṃ vivaraṃ vivaragataṃ asamphuṭṭhaṃ maṃsalohitehi upādinnaṃ—
mn140:18.5.eng: the ear canals, nostrils, and mouth; and the space for swallowing what is eaten and drunk, the space where it stays, and the space for excreting it from the nether regions; or anything else internal, personal, that’s space, spacious, and appropriated.

mn140:18.6.eng: This is called the interior space element.

mn140:18.7.pli: Yā ceva kho pana ajjhattikā ākāsadhātu yā ca bāhirā ākāsadhātu ākāsadhāturevesā.
mn140:18.7.eng: The interior space element and the exterior space element are just the space element.

mn140:18.8.pli: ‘Taṃ netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
mn140:18.8.eng: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn140:18.9.pli: Evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā ākāsadhātuyā nibbindati, ākāsadhātuyā cittaṃ virājeti.
mn140:18.9.eng: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the space element, detaching the mind from the space element.
mn140:18.9.comm: From here, MN 62:12.9 proceeds in a different direction, outlining a series of meditations based on the elements and other things.

mn140:19.1.eng: What remains is sheer consciousness, pure and bright.
mn140:19.1.comm: The phrase “sheer consciousness” (viññāṇaṁyeva) echoes Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12, where the ultimate manifestation of the Self, the “principle reality”, is said to be “a sheer mass of consciousness” (vijñānaghana eva). Here it refers to the mind following absorption that develops insight into feelings.

mn140:19.2.eng: And what does that consciousness know?

mn140:19.4.pli: Sukhavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhu, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhā vedanā.
mn140:19.4.eng: Pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
mn140:19.4.comm: Such as the pleasant feelings of the first three absorptions.

mn140:19.5.pli: So sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
mn140:19.5.eng: When they feel a pleasant feeling, they know: ‘I feel a pleasant feeling.’

mn140:19.6.pli: ‘Tasseva sukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ sukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā sukhā vedanā sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti.
mn140:19.6.eng: They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as pleasant, the corresponding pleasant feeling ceases and stops.’

mn140:19.7.pli: Dukkhavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhu, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dukkhā vedanā.
mn140:19.7.eng: Painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
mn140:19.7.comm: Such as the painful feelings that arise in the body after emergence from absorption.

mn140:19.8.pli: So dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
mn140:19.8.eng: When they feel a painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling.’

mn140:19.9.pli: ‘Tasseva dukkhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ dukkhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā dukkhā vedanā sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti.
mn140:19.9.eng: They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as painful, the corresponding painful feeling ceases and stops.’

mn140:19.10.pli: Adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhu, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati adukkhamasukhā vedanā.
mn140:19.10.eng: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
mn140:19.10.comm: Such as the neutral feeling of the fourth absorption.

mn140:19.11.pli: So adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
mn140:19.11.eng: When they feel a neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling.’

mn140:19.12.pli: ‘Tasseva adukkhamasukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā adukkhamasukhā vedanā sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti.
mn140:19.12.eng: They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.’

mn140:19.13.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, dvinnaṃ kaṭṭhānaṃ saṅghaṭṭā samodhānā usmā jāyati, tejo abhinibbattati, tesaṃyeva dvinnaṃ kaṭṭhānaṃ nānābhāvā vinikkhepā yā tajjā usmā sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammati;
mn140:19.13.eng: When you rub two sticks together, heat is generated and fire is produced. But when you part the sticks and lay them aside, any corresponding heat ceases and stops.
mn140:19.13.comm: Experience depends on the collision of disparate elements, whose friction or “resistance” (paṭigha, DN 15:20.4) sparks the light of consciousness. Hence consciousness, like fire, is beautiful but also burning (SN 35.28).

mn140:19.14.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhu, sukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhā vedanā.
mn140:19.14.eng: In the same way, pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant. …

mn140:19.15.pli: So sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.

mn140:19.16.pli: ‘Tasseva sukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ sukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā sukhā vedanā sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti.

mn140:19.17.pli: Dukkhavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhu, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dukkhā vedanā.

mn140:19.18.pli: So dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.

mn140:19.19.pli: ‘Tasseva dukkhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ dukkhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā dukkhā vedanā sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti.

mn140:19.20.pli: Adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhu, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

mn140:19.21.pli: So adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.

mn140:19.22.pli: ‘Tasseva adukkhamasukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā adukkhamasukhā vedanā sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti.
mn140:19.22.eng: They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.’

mn140:20.1.pli: Athāparaṃ upekkhāyeva avasissati parisuddhā pariyodātā mudu ca kammaññā ca pabhassarā ca.
mn140:20.1.eng: There remains only equanimity, pure, bright, pliable, workable, and radiant.
mn140:20.1.comm: This is the purified equanimity of the fourth absorption. Although the teaching is framed in terms of the development of discernment (vipassanā), nonetheless it follows the pattern of the absorptions, leading through the first four “form” absorptions to the radiant consciousness that can experience the formless.

mn140:20.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, dakkho suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā ukkaṃ bandheyya, ukkaṃ bandhitvā ukkāmukhaṃ ālimpeyya, ukkāmukhaṃ ālimpetvā saṇḍāsena jātarūpaṃ gahetvā ukkāmukhe pakkhipeyya, tamenaṃ kālena kālaṃ abhidhameyya, kālena kālaṃ udakena paripphoseyya, kālena kālaṃ ajjhupekkheyya, taṃ hoti jātarūpaṃ sudhantaṃ niddhantaṃ nīhaṭaṃ ninnītakasāvaṃ mudu ca kammaññañca pabhassarañca, yassā yassā ca piḷandhanavikatiyā ākaṅkhati—yadi paṭṭikāya yadi kuṇḍalāya yadi gīveyyakāya yadi suvaṇṇamālāya tañcassa atthaṃ anubhoti;
mn140:20.2.eng: It’s like when a deft goldsmith or a goldsmith’s apprentice prepares a forge, fires the crucible, picks up some native gold with tongs and puts it in the crucible. From time to time they fan it, from time to time they sprinkle water on it, and from time to time they just watch over it. That native gold becomes pliable, workable, and radiant, not brittle, and is ready to be worked. Then the goldsmith can successfully create any kind of ornament they want, whether a bracelet, earrings, a necklace, or a golden garland.
mn140:20.2.comm: This simile is developed further at AN 3.102:2.1.

mn140:20.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhu, athāparaṃ upekkhāyeva avasissati parisuddhā pariyodātā mudu ca kammaññā ca pabhassarā ca.
mn140:20.3.eng: In the same way, there remains only equanimity, pure, bright, pliable, workable, and radiant.

mn140:21.2.pli: ‘imañce ahaṃ upekkhaṃ evaṃ parisuddhaṃ evaṃ pariyodātaṃ ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasaṃhareyyaṃ, tadanudhammañca cittaṃ bhāveyyaṃ.
mn140:21.2.eng: ‘If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of infinite space, and develop my mind accordingly,

mn140:21.3.pli: Evaṃ me ayaṃ upekkhā tannissitā tadupādānā ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭheyya.
mn140:21.3.eng: this equanimity of mine, relying on that and grasping it, would remain for a very long time.
mn140:21.3.comm: The lifespans of rebirth in the first three formless realms is given in AN 3.116. For the gods of infinite space, it is twenty thousand eons.

mn140:21.4.pli: Imañce ahaṃ upekkhaṃ evaṃ parisuddhaṃ evaṃ pariyodātaṃ viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasaṃhareyyaṃ, tadanudhammañca cittaṃ bhāveyyaṃ.
mn140:21.4.eng: If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of infinite consciousness, and develop my mind accordingly,

mn140:21.5.pli: Evaṃ me ayaṃ upekkhā tannissitā tadupādānā ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭheyya.
mn140:21.5.eng: this equanimity of mine, relying on that and grasping it, would remain for a very long time.

mn140:21.6.pli: Imañce ahaṃ upekkhaṃ evaṃ parisuddhaṃ evaṃ pariyodātaṃ ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasaṃhareyyaṃ, tadanudhammañca cittaṃ bhāveyyaṃ.
mn140:21.6.eng: If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of nothingness, and develop my mind accordingly,

mn140:21.7.pli: Evaṃ me ayaṃ upekkhā tannissitā tadupādānā ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭheyya.
mn140:21.7.eng: this equanimity of mine, relying on that and grasping it, would remain for a very long time.

mn140:21.8.pli: Imañce ahaṃ upekkhaṃ evaṃ parisuddhaṃ evaṃ pariyodātaṃ nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasaṃhareyyaṃ, tadanudhammañca cittaṃ bhāveyyaṃ.
mn140:21.8.eng: If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and develop my mind accordingly,

mn140:21.9.pli: Evaṃ me ayaṃ upekkhā tannissitā tadupādānā ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭheyyā’ti.
mn140:21.9.eng: this equanimity of mine, relying on that and grasping it, would remain for a very long time.’

mn140:22.2.pli: ‘imañce ahaṃ upekkhaṃ evaṃ parisuddhaṃ evaṃ pariyodātaṃ ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasaṃhareyyaṃ, tadanudhammañca cittaṃ bhāveyyaṃ;
mn140:22.2.eng: ‘If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of infinite space, my mind would develop accordingly.

mn140:22.3.comm: “Conditioned” is saṅkhata, the past participle whose active verbal form is translated below as “choice”. To be “conditioned”, is to be “created” by an act of will or “choice”.

mn140:22.4.pli: Imañce ahaṃ upekkhaṃ evaṃ parisuddhaṃ evaṃ pariyodātaṃ viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasaṃhareyyaṃ, tadanudhammañca cittaṃ bhāveyyaṃ;
mn140:22.4.eng: If I were to apply this equanimity, so pure and bright, to the dimension of infinite consciousness …

mn140:22.6.pli: Imañce ahaṃ upekkhaṃ evaṃ parisuddhaṃ evaṃ pariyodātaṃ ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasaṃhareyyaṃ, tadanudhammañca cittaṃ bhāveyyaṃ;

mn140:22.8.pli: Imañce ahaṃ upekkhaṃ evaṃ parisuddhaṃ evaṃ pariyodātaṃ nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasaṃhareyyaṃ, tadanudhammañca cittaṃ bhāveyyaṃ;
mn140:22.8.eng: neither perception nor non-perception, my mind would develop accordingly.

mn140:22.10.pli: So neva taṃ abhisaṅkharoti, na abhisañcetayati bhavāya vā vibhavāya vā.
mn140:22.10.eng: They neither make a choice nor form an intention for existence or nonexistence.
mn140:22.10.comm: For the idiom “make a choice nor form an intention”, compare MN 52:4.2ff. and MN 121:11.4. | The craving for “nonexistence” (vibhava; see Snp 4.10:9.3) is the urge to annihilation, for which see MN 102:12.7.

mn140:22.11.pli: So anabhisaṅkharonto anabhisañcetayanto bhavāya vā vibhavāya vā na kiñci loke upādiyati,
mn140:22.11.eng: Because of this, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.

mn140:22.12.pli: anupādiyaṃ na paritassati, aparitassaṃ paccattaṃyeva parinibbāyati.
mn140:22.12.eng: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

mn140:22.13.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
mn140:22.13.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

mn140:23.1.pli: So sukhañce vedanaṃ vedeti, ‘sā aniccā’ti pajānāti, ‘anajjhositā’ti pajānāti, ‘anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti.
mn140:23.1.eng: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.
mn140:23.1.comm: This describes the reflective experience of the arahant.

mn140:23.2.pli: Dukkhañce vedanaṃ vedeti, ‘sā aniccā’ti pajānāti, ‘anajjhositā’ti pajānāti, ‘anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti.
mn140:23.2.eng: If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.

mn140:23.3.pli: Adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedeti, ‘sā aniccā’ti pajānāti, ‘anajjhositā’ti pajānāti, ‘anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti.
mn140:23.3.eng: If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.

mn140:24.1.pli: So sukhañce vedanaṃ vedeti, visaṃyutto naṃ vedeti;
mn140:24.1.eng: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.

mn140:24.2.pli: dukkhañce vedanaṃ vedeti, visaṃyutto naṃ vedeti;
mn140:24.2.eng: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.

mn140:24.3.pli: adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedeti, visaṃyutto naṃ vedeti.
mn140:24.3.eng: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.

mn140:24.4.pli: So kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti, jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti,
mn140:24.4.eng: Feeling the end of the body draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’

mn140:24.5.pli: ‘kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānāti.
mn140:24.5.eng: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life has come to an end, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’
mn140:24.5.comm: To “become cool” is, as the simile makes clear, to realize extinguishment (nibbāna).

mn140:24.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, telañca paṭicca vaṭṭiñca paṭicca telappadīpo jhāyati;
mn140:24.6.eng: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.

mn140:24.7.pli: tasseva telassa ca vaṭṭiyā ca pariyādānā aññassa ca anupahārā anāhāro nibbāyati;
mn140:24.7.eng: As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to not being fed.

mn140:24.8.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhu, kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti, jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti,
mn140:24.8.eng: In the same way, feeling the end of the body draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’

mn140:24.9.pli: ‘kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānāti.
mn140:24.9.eng: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life has come to an end, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’

mn140:25.1.pli: Tasmā evaṃ samannāgato bhikkhu iminā paramena paññādhiṭṭhānena samannāgato hoti.
mn140:25.1.eng: Therefore a mendicant thus endowed is endowed with the ultimate foundation of wisdom.

mn140:25.2.pli: Esā hi, bhikkhu, paramā ariyā paññā yadidaṃ—
mn140:25.2.eng: For this is the ultimate noble wisdom, namely,

mn140:25.3.eng: the knowledge of the ending of all suffering.
mn140:25.3.comm: Here ends the discussion of the first “foundation”, wisdom, which is perfected by an arahant. The remaining foundations, while each having a mundane meaning, are explained from this highest of perspectives.

mn140:26.1.pli: Tassa sā vimutti sacce ṭhitā akuppā hoti.
mn140:26.1.eng: Their freedom, being founded on truth, is unshakable.

mn140:26.2.pli: Tañhi, bhikkhu, musā yaṃ mosadhammaṃ, taṃ saccaṃ yaṃ amosadhammaṃ nibbānaṃ.
mn140:26.2.eng: For that which is false has a deceptive nature, while that which is true has an undeceptive nature—extinguishment.

mn140:26.3.pli: Tasmā evaṃ samannāgato bhikkhu iminā paramena saccādhiṭṭhānena samannāgato hoti.
mn140:26.3.eng: Therefore a mendicant thus endowed is endowed with the ultimate foundation of truth.

mn140:26.4.eng: For this is the ultimate noble truth, namely,

mn140:26.5.eng: that which has an undeceptive nature—extinguishment.

mn140:27.1.pli: Tasseva kho pana pubbe aviddasuno upadhī honti samattā samādinnā.
mn140:27.1.eng: In their ignorance, they used to acquire attachments.

mn140:27.2.pli: Tyāssa pahīnā honti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
mn140:27.2.eng: Those have been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so they are unable to arise in the future.

mn140:27.3.pli: Tasmā evaṃ samannāgato bhikkhu iminā paramena cāgādhiṭṭhānena samannāgato hoti.
mn140:27.3.eng: Therefore a mendicant thus endowed is endowed with the ultimate foundation of generosity.

mn140:27.4.pli: Eso hi, bhikkhu, paramo ariyo cāgo yadidaṃ—
mn140:27.4.eng: For this is the ultimate noble generosity, namely,

mn140:28.1.pli: Tasseva kho pana pubbe aviddasuno abhijjhā hoti chando sārāgo.
mn140:28.1.eng: In their ignorance, they used to be covetous, full of desire and lust.

mn140:28.2.pli: Svāssa pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.
mn140:28.2.eng: That has been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so it’s unable to arise in the future.

mn140:28.3.pli: Tasseva kho pana pubbe aviddasuno āghāto hoti byāpādo sampadoso.
mn140:28.3.eng: In their ignorance, they used to be contemptuous, full of ill will and malevolence.

mn140:28.4.pli: Svāssa pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.
mn140:28.4.eng: That has been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so it’s unable to arise in the future.

mn140:28.5.pli: Tasseva kho pana pubbe aviddasuno avijjā hoti sammoho.
mn140:28.5.eng: In their ignorance, they used to be ignorant, full of delusion.

mn140:28.6.pli: Svāssa pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.
mn140:28.6.eng: That has been cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so it’s unable to arise in the future.

mn140:28.7.pli: Tasmā evaṃ samannāgato bhikkhu iminā paramena upasamādhiṭṭhānena samannāgato hoti.
mn140:28.7.eng: Therefore a mendicant thus endowed is endowed with the ultimate foundation of peace.

mn140:28.8.pli: Eso hi, bhikkhu, paramo ariyo upasamo yadidaṃ—
mn140:28.8.eng: For this is the ultimate noble peace, namely,

mn140:28.9.eng: the pacification of greed, hate, and delusion.

mn140:29.1.pli: ‘Paññaṃ nappamajjeyya, saccamanurakkheyya, cāgamanubrūheyya, santimeva so sikkheyyā’ti—
mn140:29.1.eng: ‘Do not neglect wisdom; preserve truth; foster generosity; and train only for peace.’

mn140:29.2.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn140:29.2.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
mn140:29.2.comm: This concludes the discussion of the four foundations.

mn140:30.1.pli: ‘Yattha ṭhitaṃ maññassavā nappavattanti, maññassave kho pana nappavattamāne muni santoti vuccatī’ti—
mn140:30.1.eng: ‘Where they stand, the streams of conceiving do not flow. And where the streams of conceiving do not flow, they are called a sage at peace.’
mn140:30.1.comm: “Streams of conceiving” (maññassavā) is a unique image, allied to the notion that defilements may “stream on to” a person (āsavā assaveyyuṁ, AN 4.195:2.2).

mn140:30.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn140:30.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn140:31.1.pli: ‘Asmī’ti, bhikkhu, maññitametaṃ, ‘ayamahamasmī’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘na bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘rūpī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘arūpī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘saññī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘asaññī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘nevasaññīnāsaññī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ.
mn140:31.1.eng: These are all forms of conceiving: ‘I am’, ‘I am this’, ‘I will be’, ‘I will not be’, ‘I will have form’, ‘I will be formless’, ‘I will be percipient’, ‘I will be non-percipient’, ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient.’

mn140:31.2.pli: Maññitaṃ, bhikkhu, rogo maññitaṃ gaṇḍo maññitaṃ sallaṃ.
mn140:31.2.eng: Conceiving is a disease, a boil, a dart.

mn140:31.3.pli: Sabbamaññitānaṃ tveva, bhikkhu, samatikkamā muni santoti vuccati.
mn140:31.3.eng: Having gone beyond all conceiving, one is called a sage at peace.

mn140:31.4.pli: Muni kho pana, bhikkhu, santo na jāyati, na jīyati, na mīyati, na kuppati, na piheti.
mn140:31.4.eng: The sage at peace is not reborn, does not grow old, and does not die. They are not shaken, and do not yearn.

mn140:31.5.pli: Tañhissa, bhikkhu, natthi yena jāyetha, ajāyamāno kiṃ jīyissati, ajīyamāno kiṃ mīyissati, amīyamāno kiṃ kuppissati, akuppamāno kissa pihessati?
mn140:31.5.eng: For they have nothing which would cause them to be reborn. Not being reborn, how could they grow old? Not growing old, how could they die? Not dying, how could they be shaken? Not shaking, for what could they yearn?

mn140:32.1.pli: ‘Yattha ṭhitaṃ maññassavā nappavattanti, maññassave kho pana nappavattamāne muni santoti vuccatī’ti—
mn140:32.1.eng: ‘Where they stand, the streams of conceiving do not flow. And where the streams of conceiving do not flow, they are called a sage at peace.’

mn140:32.2.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn140:32.2.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn140:32.3.pli: Imaṃ kho me tvaṃ, bhikkhu, saṅkhittena chadhātuvibhaṅgaṃ dhārehī”ti.
mn140:32.3.eng: Mendicant, you should remember this brief analysis of the six elements.”
mn140:32.3.comm: The “brief analysis” here is the summary teaching around which the sutta is developed (MN 140:7.4).

mn140:33.2.pli: “satthā kira me anuppatto, sugato kira me anuppatto, sammāsambuddho kira me anuppatto”ti uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ cīvaraṃ katvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn140:33.2.eng: “It seems the Teacher has come to me! The Holy One has come to me! The fully awakened Buddha has come to me!” He got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet, and said,

mn140:33.3.pli: “accayo maṃ, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṃ yathāmūḷhaṃ yathāakusalaṃ, yohaṃ bhagavantaṃ āvusovādena samudācaritabbaṃ amaññissaṃ.
mn140:33.3.eng: “I made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me to presume to address the Buddha as ‘reverend’.

mn140:33.4.pli: Tassa me, bhante, bhagavā accayaṃ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṃ saṃvarāyā”ti.
mn140:33.4.eng: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”

mn140:33.5.pli: “Taggha tvaṃ, bhikkhu, accayo accagamā yathābālaṃ yathāmūḷhaṃ yathāakusalaṃ, yaṃ maṃ tvaṃ āvusovādena samudācaritabbaṃ amaññittha.
mn140:33.5.eng: “Indeed, mendicant, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to act in that way.

mn140:33.6.pli: Yato ca kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikarosi, taṃ te mayaṃ paṭiggaṇhāma.
mn140:33.6.eng: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.

mn140:33.7.pli: Vuddhihesā, bhikkhu, ariyassa vinaye yo accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikaroti, āyatiṃ saṃvaraṃ āpajjatī”ti.
mn140:33.7.eng: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.”

mn140:34.1.eng: “Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”

mn140:34.2.eng: “But mendicant, do you have a full set of bowl and robes?”
mn140:34.2.comm: This is one of the questions asked of an ordination candidate (Kd 1:76.1.14). A mendicant is expected to have a bowl—made of metal or clay, not too big or too small—and three robes—the lower robe or sabong (antaravāsaka), the upper robe (uttarasaṅga), and the double-layered outer cloak (saṅghāṭi). In the suttas, the Buddha does not usually ask this question, so he must have observed that Pukkusāti, who had renounced of his own volition, lacked the proper requisites.

mn140:34.4.eng: “The Realized Ones do not ordain those without a full set of bowl and robes.”

mn140:35.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā pukkusāti bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pattacīvarapariyesanaṃ pakkāmi.
mn140:35.1.eng: And then Venerable Pukkusāti approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

mn140:35.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmantaṃ pukkusātiṃ pattacīvarapariyesanaṃ carantaṃ vibbhantā gāvī jīvitā voropesi.
mn140:35.2.eng: But while he was wandering in search of a bowl and robes, a stray cow took his life.
mn140:35.2.comm: Cows were normally regarded as gentle creatures (Snp 2.7:27.1). They sometimes become violent, however, especially when protecting young calves, resulting in the tragic fates of Bāhiya (Ud 1.10:10.2) and Suppabuddha (Ud 5.3:7.2). Attacks by cows still occur today in India and wherever cows are raised.

mn140:36.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn140:36.1.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

mn140:36.2.pli: “yo so, bhante, pukkusāti nāma kulaputto bhagavatā saṅkhittena ovādena ovadito so kālaṅkato.
mn140:36.2.eng: “Sir, the gentleman named Pukkusāti, who was advised in brief by the Buddha, has passed away.

mn140:36.3.eng: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”

mn140:36.4.pli: “Paṇḍito, bhikkhave, pukkusāti kulaputto paccapādi dhammassānudhammaṃ, na ca maṃ dhammādhikaraṇaṃ vihesesi.
mn140:36.4.eng: “Mendicants, Pukkusāti was astute. He practiced in line with the teaching, and did not trouble me about the teachings.

mn140:36.5.pli: Pukkusāti, bhikkhave, kulaputto pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā”ti.
mn140:36.5.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters, he’s been reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.”
mn140:36.5.comm: Pukkusāti is one of a group of seven who attained arahantship in the Pure Abode of Aviha (SN 1.50:3.2, SN 2.24:4.2).

mn140:36.6.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn140:36.7.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn140:36.7.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
